documents.title: that 's it for today !
text: thanks everyone for your questions , and to ian for answering as many as he could so brilliantly .
until next time !
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 4:05pm it 's been fun chatting .
til the next time .
miwindcusa asks : is working with derek jacobi on vicious as much fun as it seems to be ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 4:02pm absolutely not .
it 's hell from beginning to end .
elena konstantinidis asks : so i have to ask the question : what do you think was sherlock holmes gay ?
and/or what was his relationship with john watson ?
i am very exited for the movie !
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 4:00pm well , he 's not gay in our film .
indeed , the romantic part of the film is about his relationship with a lady in grey .
anneelkmiss asks : i remember watching you as iago on video when was studying othello for a level .
what do you like best about playing villains ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:59pm iago is a very easy part to play .
he must just appear to be as charming and helpful and reliable as all the characters in the play think him to be .
then when he 's on his own , he can turn to the audience and tell them the truth : that he 's as nasty as they come .
no acting required , really .
holdenandco asks : there 's some footage of the mr. holmes shoot on youtube .
actors on set in period costumes are shown checking their cell phones while waiting for shots to begin .
is this distracting for an actor in a period film ?

guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:58pm it always baffles me as to how many friends people on their cellphones seem to have , until i lean over their shoulder and i realise they 're playing some game .
they 're playing solitaire , and disguising how lonely and miserable they are .
mã­kel kobarpulos says : a very merry unbirthday to you sir ian !
is there a story you 'd like to see adapted to a film or a play in which you 'd want to have a role ?
xo from mexico : p guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:57pm edmund hillary 's life .
it 's full of highs and depressions .
he and my father looked very alike , so perhaps i do too .
nathan malin ( age 15 ) asks : i had the privilege of seeing you and mr. stewart perform in waiting for godot on broadway a few years ago .
i am an aspiring young actor , and as time went on , waiting for godot quickly became my favorite play , and i studied and did scene work on it where i played didi in my high school drama class .
i would like to ask you the most rudimentary question about the play : who do you think godot is ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:56pm he 's a farmer .
and he does n't keep his appointments .
leigh balmforth asks : i regard you very highly as a gay man and a superb actor !
would you possibly spill the beans as to who has been a nightmare to work with and who a joy ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:55pm i do n't find it easy working with balthazar in vicious .
he just lies around with his legs wide open , and he smells .
i 'm glad none of that is true of sir derek .
shamim khaliq asks : my 11 year old son wants to be an actor .
i 'm poor .
he 's got weekly drama and music classes courtesy of the â£ 300/month his dad sends him .
is there a route into acting for poor people ?
are performing arts academies any good ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:54pm i suggest when he 's old enough that your son applies to the national youth theatre .
as good a way as any of confirming that love of theatre might develop into a career .
sammy gamgee asks : when filming the lord of the rings and hobbit trilogy did you ever think wow it 's her , or him .
did you meet anyone who you thought you would never get to meet ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:53pm cate blanchett , cate blanchett , cate blanchett .
while playing galadriel , she was also directing the sydney theatre company , so we could gossip about theatre as well as film in between takes .
alexxe asks : hello , sir .
i met you on the set for emile , the carl bessai film that you shot in victoria , british columbia in 2002 .
i was working background .
you were so lovely to everyone , myself included and because of you craft services could feed us , so thank you .
i think the film turned out beautifully .
what drew you to the piece ?
and was there anything about victoria that still stands out for you ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:52pm thank you for the happy memories of emile , which i helped to write .
in victoria i bought a marble tail of a whale which i see every day in my bathroom .
lordvoldemort98 asks : sir ian , who is your favorite actor ?
: ) guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:50pm i do n't have a favourite , and if i did i would n't tell you - i 'd lose too many friends .

documents.title: `` i think of work as play ''
text: lindadunning asks : how do you find the time to do so much work ?
i 'm 68 and find my time getting slimmer .
good on you sir ianxxxx guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:49pm i think of work as play .
something to stimulate and enjoy .
and i take a nap in the afternoon .
linny may asks : what prompted the video with george ezra ?
( i loved it ) guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:48pm george did ( i love him ) .
if you do n't know what this is about , here you go , dear readers ( do n't miss minute 2:20 ) :
sherlocksgirl asks : what makes your sherlock holmes different to the others apart from being the oldest and why should people watch the movie ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:47pm 4 ) i ca n't imagine wanting to spend any downtime with sherlock holmes .
he 's so bossy , and sure of himself .
the revelation of our mr holmes is that the real sherlock is full of self-doubt and capable of learning to like and even love other people .
louise broadbent asks : you are a fantastic stage actor .
are there any roles that you would have liked to play on stage , that you have n't played ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:46pm i 'm sorry that i sha n't be playing antonio in the merchant of venice .
nor , now , mercutio .
but you can keep falstaff , because it 's the most difficult part ever .
mind you , antony sher more than gets away with it , as usual .
lordvoldemort98 asks : what is your worst fear ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:45pm professionally - forgetting my lines .
elsewhere - being in a car crash .

documents.title: `` i 've always wanted to play an elderly mercutio in romeo and juliet ''
text: benji bailey asks : do you think it 's possible you 'll be returning to shakespeare or the rsc in the future ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:43pm if i were to do another shakespeare play i hope it would be at the rsc , which is thriving under the directorship of greg doran .
i 've always wanted to play an elderly mercutio in romeo and juliet , and a close friend of mine of similar age has got there first .

documents.title: `` if i had n't been an actor , i would have been either a chef , a journalist or a teacher ''
text: id3051408 asks : what would your job have been if acting had n't crossed your path ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:42pm either a chef , a journalist , or a teacher .
had i done any of these i would have probably retired by now .
haydn curtis asks : do you think its harder for working class kids to get jobs in acting nowadays , as it seems the british talent today are all private school- and cambridge-educated ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:41pm cambridge university has long dominated british theatre because of the directors and actors who worked together as like-minded undergraduates .
i 'm sure many a drama school would make the same claim .
if there is a problem for tyro actors it is the difficulty of funding their training which does give an advantage to someone whose parents can afford to pay the fees .
there are many ways of providing scholarships through public or private funding .
i did n't go to drama school , but i had an apprenticeship in the regional theatre companies which do n't exist any more .
nivlek47 asks : who do you think has made the best film version of a shakespeare play ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:38pm on my website , www.mckellen.com , you will find for free my screenplay for richard iii .
plus notes explaining every decision that was made .
i would n't like to say richard iii was better than any other film of shakespeare .
particularly with laurence olivier 's version of the same play looming over my efforts .

documents.title: no man 's land will tour the uk and play in london in the summer of 2016
text: colinbell52 asks : will you reprise your broadway appearance with patrick stewart in pinter 's no man 's land in the uk ?
we miss you in the theatre and hope so !
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:36pm yes !
you hear it here first .
no man 's land will tour the uk and play in london in the summer of 2016 .
the script is sensationally speakable , and although it was a big success on broadway i think the play with its references to cricket and the class system properly belongs in england .
lucy mckee asks : i am currently directing an adaptation of king lear for the edinburgh fringe this summer .
we are working with sixth form students and we cast a female lear .
what advice would you give her , or to any young actor , to try and capture the essence of lear , especially to overcome the age difference ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:35pm i do n't think she should spend too much effort trying to be a man , otherwise you would cast a man , would n't you ?
but what is essential is to convey the character 's age , as the story is crucially about his decreasing grasp on reality .

alise ratliff asks : first , i would like to say that you have been my hero for 13 years , ever since i was very young and my question is , through out your acting career what would you say is your favorite memory while performing and why ?

guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:34pm i think touring the national theatre 's production of coriolanus to athens , and stepping onto the open air stage below the acropolis , and seeing the parthenon illuminated high above the auditorium .
john brownbill asks : i am a huge sherlock holmes fan , how would you say your performance differs from the likes of robert downey jr , benedict cumberbatch and jonny lee miller ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:33pm you mention the three latest actors to have a success as sherlock holmes - before them there were hundreds of others .
i 'm just the latest but certainly the oldest mr holmes .
rameau asks : what is your relationship with bbw these days ?
burnley , bolton and wigan guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:32pm i 'm in wigan next week .
i think i 'll suggest you should google why
squiffy1 asks : they say variety is the s of life , however , is there something in common with all the scripts you have been sent that makes you accept the role ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:30pm yes - what connects all the varied jobs i do is the quality of the scripts .
as an audience and as an actor i do n't start criticising a pantomime for not being shakespeare , or vice versa .
jess pagan asks : you have an involvement with the little theatre guild , which is a fantastic group trying to give volunteering opportunities for those wanting to get involved in theatre and drama .
how important to you are these types of groups for young actors/theatre workers ?
it 's such a shame old theatres are closing down due to council decisions .
thank you !
p.s .
i volunteer at the doncaster little theatre !
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:30pm as patron of the little theatre guild i 've been able to visit scores of amateur companies up and down the country .
everywhere is the same - enormous enthusiasm for the idea of theatre , working with friends , and entertaining the audience .
it 's exactly the same for us professionals .

buntylevert asks : in light of your ownership/involvement in one of the ever-dwindling bastions of the great traditional pub in london ( the grapes ) , do you feel the traditional pub as we know it will still be here in 50 years ?

guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:28pm pubs are closing all over the place , but the grapes seems to be thriving : perhaps because it 's a home from home for the locals which gives us an authenticity which appeals to the tourists who want to go see the river and an ancient building .
iantonia asks : of all the supernatural powers you have had as an actor or that have appeared in your movies , which power would you like to have ?
you can only choose one !
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:26pm to fly .
callum cormie asks : hi ian .
there 's been a huge debate about the current trend of superhero films and whether its a good thing for movies or not .
considering your role in the x-men movies , what 's your take on it ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:26pm i caught up with iron man 3 the other day .
if all the other superhero movies are as good as that , why should we be worried ?
it was so funny , brilliantly acted .
i suppose i better watch robert as sherlock sometime .
spacemouse asks : you have worked with some of the world 's greatest directors/actors but which project was the most fun to do and why ?

also were their any projects that were hellish ( give us the juice ) : ) guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:25pm i can honestly say i 've enjoyed every job i 've had as an actor , on stage and screen , and indeed radio .
a couple i regret because i simply could n't get into the part .
but of course i sha n't confide which they were .

daveydor asks : dear sir ian , or serena if i may use mr. fry 's term , you mentioned years ago your unfulfilled ambitions to appear in panto and in coronation street ; you 've since done them both what 's left on your wish-list ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:24pm until recently i would have said to sing and dance in a disney musical .
lo and behold , i 'm playing cogsworth the clock in beauty and the beast .
susie garner asks : what has been your favourite role ?
x guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:22pm well macbeth .
coriolanus .
richard iii .
king lear .
everything i 've done in chekov .
galdalf the grey .
gogo in waiting for godot .
and now guess what sherlock holmes .

documents.title: `` i too am baffled by the number of people needed to make a film ''
text: mszuzu asks : whenever i watch the credits after a film , i 'm blown away by the sheer number of people involved in making it .
i do n't even understand most of their job titles , much less what they actually do .
in your experience , who are the unsung heroes of any film set ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:21pm i too am baffled by the number of people needed to make a film , particularly one with special effects .
i always feel duty bound to watch , and even read , the names of any film that i am in .
it 's the least expression of thanks that i can give .
you could sympathise with those gardeners in the `` green '' department who keep the vegetation looking fresh even when it 's made of plastic .

documents.title: on coming out : `` take courage from the fact that every gay person who is out has shared your worries ''
text: sweatha ranganath asks , from dubai : what advice do you have for the younger generation who face problems with coming out of the closet ?
they often keep in mind the reaction of their kith and kin or the society as a large .

as a bisexual myself who recently came out of the closet with my parents and faced a great deal of pressure and negative thoughts , i would like to ask you if there is any way we can overcome the fear of the same ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:18pm everyone who is in the process of coming out as a gay person worries about how others will take it .
that 's why i recommend starting your coming out journey by talking to a close friend , then a sibling or cousin .
so that by the time that you 're telling your parents ( they probably know anyway ) you will have some support .
take courage from the fact that every gay person who is out has shared your worries .
tonyajarrett asks : sir ian , there 's a lot of malarkey in acting training , differing methods , etc .
can you cut through all that and talk about the cleanest , most direct way to start in building a character , how you approach it ?
do you start with the text and work your way in ?
or perhaps as olivier did , coming up with the outward appearance and finding the character that way .
thank you !

guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:16pm i always start with the text , to get some objective view of the character , but acting only starts once you take that character inside yourself .
and give it reality through your own voice , body , face .

guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:15pm all you need is a brilliant script : tolkien , rowling , or someone else .
mariocavaradossi asks : if you could go back in time and see any shakespeare performance , which would it be ?

guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:14pm i would like to see the first performance of the merchant of venice , and confirm what i suspect shakespeare intended : that the merchant , antonio , is an openly gay man .
as in the recent royal shakespeare company production .
lordvoldemort98 asks : sir ian , in your opinion , what are the most important qualities in a human being ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:14pm i suppose empathy , so that you try and understand what it feels like to be the other person .
it 's what actors try and do .
wendy hsiao asks : would you ever consider beekeeping yourself and did learning it for the film help you channel holmes ?
guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:13pm i was very taken with the bees .
and learned not to be nervous .
they are of course very busy doing their own thing and have no interest in stinging human beings unless they get in the way .
i 'm quite proud of not getting stung - nor was a bee harmed during the filming of mr holmes .

documents.title: the worst wig he ever wore ? the one on scandal
text: charlotte ward asks : hello mr mck .
what was the worst wig you ever wore for a performance and why ?

( i 'm guessing gandolf and weight ) charlotte guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:12pm i hesitate to draw people 's attention to it , but my hair in the film scandal was much commented on , and mocked , and reviled , so that the critics missed the performance underneath .
id1470876 asks : sir ian , if you could time travel , what one piece of advice would you give to your younger self ?

guardian contributor ianmckellen1 05 june 2015 3:11pm i would tell ian in the words of the recent campaign , `` it gets better '' , meaning that you will gain the self-confidence that you did n't have in your youth .

documents.title: post your questions for ian mckellen
text: it requires an actor of some gravity to take on yet another portrayal of sherlock holmes but if anyone has the chops , then it 's ian mckellen .
from richard iii to the da vinci code , gods and monsters to coronation street , mckellen 's ability to swing from beckett to hollywood marks him as one of britain 's greatest actors .

his new film mr holmes , in which the detective frets over an unsolved case in the twilight of his years , contrasts with the wisecracking recent incarnations by robert downey jr and benedict cumberbatch .

it 's a chance for mckellen to take centre stage on screen , after years adding ensemble ballast to the lord of the rings and x-men films - and a nice contrast to his other current role , the catty freddie thornhill in itv sitcom vicious .

the cricket fan , pub landlord and energetic champion of lgbt rights is joining us from 3pm bst onwards on friday 5 june to answer your questions post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .
